title: Polygon
text:
In <a href="geometry">geometry</a>, a polygon () is a <a href="plane%20%28mathematics%29">plane</a> <a href="Shape">figure</a> that is described by a finite number of straight <a href="line%20segment">line segment</a>s connected to form a closed "<a href="polygonal%20chain">polygonal chain</a>" (or "polygonal circuit"). The bounded plane <a href="region%20%28mathematics%29">region</a>, the bounding circuit, or the two together, may be called a polygon.
The segments of a polygonal circuit are called its "<a href="edge%20%28geometry%29">edges</a>" or "sides". The points where two edges meet are the polygon's "<a href="Vertex%20%28geometry%29">vertices</a>" (singular: vertex) or "corners". The interior of a solid polygon is sometimes called its "body". An "n"-gon is a polygon with "n" sides; for example, a <a href="triangle">triangle</a> is a 3-gon.
A <a href="simple%20polygon">simple polygon</a> is one which does not intersect itself. Mathematicians are often concerned only with the bounding polygonal chains of simple polygons and they often define a polygon accordingly. A polygonal boundary may be allowed to cross over itself, creating <a href="star%20polygon">star polygon</a>s and other <a href="list%20of%20self-intersecting%20polygons">self-intersecting polygons</a>.
A polygon is a 2-dimensional example of the more general <a href="polytope">polytope</a> in any number of dimensions. There are many more <a href="%23Generalizations">generalizations of polygons</a> defined for different purposes.
Etymology.
The word "polygon" derives from the <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> adjective πολύς ("polús") 'much', 'many' and γωνία ("gōnía") 'corner' or 'angle'. It has been suggested that γόνυ ("gónu") 'knee' may be the origin of "gon".
Classification.
Number of sides.
Polygons are primarily classified by the number of sides. See the <a href="%23Naming">table below</a>.

Equality and symmetry.
The property of regularity may be defined in other ways: a polygon is regular if and only if it is both isogonal and isotoxal, or equivalently it is both cyclic and equilateral. A non-convex regular polygon is called a "regular <a href="star%20polygon">star polygon</a>".

The signed area depends on the ordering of the vertices and of the <a href="orientation%20%28vector%20space%29">orientation</a> of the plane. Commonly, the positive orientation is defined by the (counterclockwise) rotation that maps the positive -axis to the positive -axis. If the vertices are ordered counterclockwise (that is, according to positive orientation), the signed area is positive; otherwise, it is negative. In either case, the area formula is correct in <a href="absolute%20value">absolute value</a>. This is commonly called the <a href="shoelace%20formula">shoelace formula</a> or Surveyor's formula.
The area "A" of a simple polygon can also be computed if the lengths of the sides, "a"1, "a"2, ..., "an" and the <a href="exterior%20angle">exterior angle</a>s, "θ"1, "θ"2, ..., "θn" are known, from:
The formula was described by Lopshits in 1963.
If the polygon can be drawn on an equally spaced grid such that all its vertices are grid points, <a href="Pick%27s%20theorem">Pick's theorem</a> gives a simple formula for the polygon's area based on the numbers of interior and boundary grid points: the former number plus one-half the latter number, minus 1.
In every polygon with perimeter "p" and area "A ", the <a href="isoperimetric%20inequality">isoperimetric inequality</a> formula_13 holds.
For any two simple polygons of equal area, the <a href="Bolyai%E2%80%93Gerwien%20theorem">Bolyai–Gerwien theorem</a> asserts that the first can be cut into polygonal pieces which can be reassembled to form the second polygon.
The lengths of the sides of a polygon do not in general determine its area. However, if the polygon is simple and cyclic then the sides "do" determine the area. Of all "n"-gons with given side lengths, the one with the largest area is cyclic. Of all "n"-gons with a given perimeter, the one with the largest area is regular (and therefore cyclic).

Generalizations.
The idea of a polygon has been generalized in various ways. Some of the more important include:
Naming.
The word "polygon" comes from <a href="Late%20Latin">Late Latin</a> "polygōnum" (a noun), from <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> πολύγωνον ("polygōnon/polugōnon"), noun use of neuter of πολύγωνος ("polygōnos/polugōnos", the masculine adjective), meaning "many-angled". Individual polygons are named (and sometimes classified) according to the number of sides, combining a <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>-derived <a href="numerical%20prefix">numerical prefix</a> with the suffix "-gon", e.g. "<a href="pentagon">pentagon</a>", "<a href="dodecagon">dodecagon</a>". The <a href="triangle">triangle</a>, <a href="quadrilateral">quadrilateral</a> and <a href="nonagon">nonagon</a> are exceptions.
Beyond decagons (10-sided) and dodecagons (12-sided), mathematicians generally use numerical notation, for example 17-gon and 257-gon.
Exceptions exist for side counts that are easily expressed in verbal form (e.g. 20 and 30), or are used by non-mathematicians. Some special polygons also have their own names; for example the <a href="regular%20polygon">regular</a> <a href="star%20polygon">star</a> <a href="pentagon">pentagon</a> is also known as the <a href="pentagram">pentagram</a>.

History.
Polygons have been known since ancient times. The <a href="regular%20polygon">regular polygon</a>s were known to the ancient Greeks, with the <a href="pentagram">pentagram</a>, a non-convex regular polygon (<a href="star%20polygon">star polygon</a>), appearing as early as the 7th century B.C. on a <a href="krater">krater</a> by <a href="Aristophanes%20%28vase%20painter%29">Aristophanes</a>, found at <a href="Caere">Caere</a> and now in the <a href="Capitoline%20Museum">Capitoline Museum</a>.
The first known systematic study of non-convex polygons in general was made by <a href="Thomas%20Bradwardine">Thomas Bradwardine</a> in the 14th century.
In 1952, <a href="Geoffrey%20Colin%20Shephard">Geoffrey Colin Shephard</a> generalized the idea of polygons to the complex plane, where each <a href="real%20number">real</a> dimension is accompanied by an <a href="imaginary%20number">imaginary</a> one, to create <a href="complex%20polytope">complex polygons</a>.
In nature.
Polygons appear in rock formations, most commonly as the flat facets of <a href="crystal">crystal</a>s, where the angles between the sides depend on the type of mineral from which the crystal is made.
Regular hexagons can occur when the cooling of <a href="lava">lava</a> forms areas of tightly packed columns of <a href="basalt">basalt</a>, which may be seen at the <a href="Giant%27s%20Causeway">Giant's Causeway</a> in <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>, or at the <a href="Devil%27s%20Postpile">Devil's Postpile</a> in <a href="California">California</a>.
In <a href="biology">biology</a>, the surface of the wax <a href="honeycomb">honeycomb</a> made by <a href="bee">bee</a>s is an array of <a href="hexagon">hexagon</a>s, and the sides and base of each cell are also polygons.
Computer graphics.
In <a href="computer%20graphics">computer graphics</a>, a polygon is a <a href="geometric%20primitive">primitive</a> used in modelling and rendering. They are defined in a database, containing arrays of <a href="vertex%20%28computer%20graphics%29">vertices</a> (the coordinates of the <a href="vertex%20%28geometry%29">geometrical vertices</a>, as well as other attributes of the polygon, such as color, shading and texture), connectivity information, and <a href="material%20%28computer%20graphics%29">materials</a>.
Any surface is modelled as a tessellation called <a href="polygon%20mesh">polygon mesh</a>. If a square mesh has points (vertices) per side, there are "n" squared squares in the mesh, or 2"n" squared triangles since there are two triangles in a square. There are vertices per triangle. Where "n" is large, this approaches one half. Or, each vertex inside the square mesh connects four edges (lines).
The imaging system calls up the structure of polygons needed for the scene to be created from the database. This is transferred to active memory and finally, to the display system (screen, TV monitors etc.) so that the scene can be viewed. During this process, the imaging system renders polygons in correct perspective ready for transmission of the processed data to the display system. Although polygons are two-dimensional, through the system computer they are placed in a visual scene in the correct three-dimensional orientation.
In computer graphics and <a href="computational%20geometry">computational geometry</a>, it is often necessary to determine whether a given point formula_23 lies inside a simple polygon given by a sequence of line segments. This is called the <a href="point%20in%20polygon">point in polygon</a> test.
